title: Performance of faba bean and other rabi legumes in different cropping systems in Haryana (India)[Vicia faba]
author: R Kumar and RC Singh and M Singh
abstract: A field experiment was conducted at the Research Farm of Haryana Agricultural University in Hisar during the 1988-90 winter seasons. The feasibility of faba bean sole cropping and intercropping system with chickpea in comparison with traditional rabi (winter season) legumes was compared under rainfed conditions. The soil was sandy loam in texture. low in available N (130 kg/ha). medium in available P (16.2 kg/ha). and high in K (304.5 kg/ha) with a pH value of 8.4. A basal dose of 100 kg diammonium phosphate (18: 46: 0) was placed below the seed at the time of sowing. Eleven treatments consisting of chickpea. peas. lentil. and linseed as sole as well as intercrop were replicated three times in a randomized block design. The results revealed that growing of faba bean as both sole crop and as intercrop in chickpea (2: 2) is a viable approach for sustainable productivity in terms of total grain yield and chickpea equivalent/ha. Although intercropping of faba bean with chickpea (2: 2) reduced the yield of chickpea by 51.4. the chickpea equivalent yield was higher in this combination than the yield of chickpea as a pure crop

title: Time for Reappraisal
author: Anil Bhatti and Dinesh Mohan and Mushirul Hasan and Gautami Bhoumick and Vimal Thorat and Ravinder Kumar and DL Sheth and A Mangalagiri and S Ramesh and C Rajmohan and Anil Sadgopal and Irfan Habib
abstract: IT is a time of great sadness. 1 ne ferment on the streets of urban north India has culminated in the deaths of young men and women. This is a symptom of a loss of faith in the future of our society. But it is also a time for reappraisal of our goals and the strategies to achieve them. It appears that the reason for the tragic acts of self-immolation and destruction of public property lies in the conception of the agitators that their employment opportunities in government will be restricted by reservations for those underprivileged castes/classes which are today grossly under-represen ted. The Mandal Commission Report has its own logic. which is not purely caste based. It is true that it makes only a limited beginning by providing opportunities in government to educationally and socially backward castes and classes. Nevertheless. these recommendations do represent some attempt to change the status quo which at present is …

title: A STUDY ON SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT OF TOURISM WITH REFERENCE TO INDIA
author: S Mohan and R Kumar
abstract: Tourism is an attractive tool for economic development. specifically in the developing world. Tourism has assisted many developing countries to move away from a dependency on agriculture and manufacturing. Chosen for its ability to bring in needed foreign exchange earnings. income and employment. tourism has become a popular addition to economic development policies in many African. Asian. South and Central American countries. Although tourism seems to be adding substantially to the economic growth of many of these regions. many developing countries are not reaping full benefits from tourism. Understanding the many ways that tourism profits can leak out of an economy. and devising strategies to minimize leakage could make tourism a more effective economic development agent. Tourism has emerged as a global phenomenon and the potential for tourism to generate economic development was …

title: Evaluation Of Simplified Concentration Method For Detection Of Tubercle Bacilli In Sputum Samples
author: B Khurana and Raj Kumar
abstract: Sputum samples of 3000 pulmonary tuberculosis patients were evaluated by simplified concentration method. 1000 samples were examined by three methods: Direct smear. Petroff’s concentration method and Simplified concentration method. Acid fast bacilli were present in 10%. 14.5% and 14.8% by various techniques respectively. Remaining 2000 samples were examined only by two methods: Direct smear and Simplified concentration methods and positivity was 13.95% and 17.95% respectively. Cultures of 500 sputum samples isolated mycobacteria in 80 patients. Simplified technique yielded better results of acid fast bacilli and was superior to either direct smear examination or examination of smears by Petroff’s concentration method.

title: Effect of different concentrations of diphtheria toxoid & aluminum phosphate on potency of diphtheria component in DPT vaccines.
author: PRAMOD Gupta and SN Saxena and A Kumar
journal: The Indian journal of medical research
abstract: An effort was made to determine the optimum concentration of diphtheria toxoid in combination with aluminum phosphate gel in DPT vaccines which may give a safe. potent and economical preparation. The effect of four different concentrations of aluminum phosphate and three different antigenic concentrations of diphtheria toxoid on potency of diphtheria component in DPT vaccine was assessed. A gradual increase in potency was seen with increase in toxoid concentration and a gradual decrease in potency with the increase in aluminum phosphate content. Vaccines made with minimum quantities of toxoid (30 Lf/ml) and aluminum phosphate (3 mg/ml) were found to be highly satisfactory. Vaccines prepared with high antigenic purity toxoid have better potency. as compared to those prepared with a relatively low antigenic purity toxoid.

title: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF INDUSTRIAL PHARMACY AND BIO SCIENCES
author: Chetan Salwan and Rajwinder Kumar and AS Mann
abstract: Indian rennet (Withania coagulans dunal L.) is used in traditional medicine. Total antioxidant activity in 23 Iranian rennet accessions was determined as Trolox equivalent antioxidant capacity (TEAC). Total phenolic contents were determined using a spectrophotometric technique. based on the Folin-Ciocalteau reagent. according to the method of Spanos and Wrolstad [Journal of Agricultural & Food Chemistry. 38 (1990) 1565] and calculated as gallic acid equiva-lents GAE/g dw. Total antioxidant activity varied from 10.8 to 35.7 mM Trolox. and total phenolic content ranged from 22.9 to 65.5 mg gallic acid/g dw in ‘‘Dezful I’’and ‘‘Babol’’accessions. respectively. A linear positive relationship existed between the antioxidant activity and total phenolic acids content of the tested basil accessions (R 2= 0.71). Iranian basils possess valuable anti-oxidant properties for culinary and possible medicinal use.

title: Germination studies in finger millet (Eleusine coracana L.).
author: R Kumar and P Katiyar and RP Vyas and RP Katiyar
abstract: see more details were tested for germination in 3 media (between papers. on top of paper and in sand) at 20 or 30 C or alternating temp.(16/8 h) of 20/30. Germination at 20 and 20/30 was higher than at 30. In cv. KM-13 germination in between the papers and on top of the paper was similar and higher than in sand. In cv. Nirmal germination was highest on top of the paper at 20 and in between the papers at other temp.

title: A note on the coefficients of Hilbert polynomial
author: Ravinder Kumar
journal: Journal of Mathematics of Kyoto University
abstract: Let (Q. m) be a local ring of dimension d and q an m-primary ideal. It is well known that for sufficiently large values of n (notation: n» 0) 1. 2 (Qlqn+ 1). the length of the Q-module Q/q n+ 1 is a uniquely determined polynomial of degree d. called the Hilbert polynomial and is given by n+(n+ d—lQ (Qlqn+ 1)= e0 (d— e l (\—1)+(-1) ded where the integers e „. e l. ed depend on q and are known as normalized Hilbert coefficients. ei is sometimes written as ei (q) to emphasize its dependence on q. It is easily seen that e. is positive. In case Q is a Cohen-Macaulay ring. Northcott [2] showed that e l is non-negative and Narita [1] showed that in this case e2 is non-negative as well. Narita gave an example of a Cohen-Macaulay ring and an m-primary ideal q such that e3 (q) is negative. The purpose of this note is to show that for any integer d 3. it is possible to construct an example of a Cohen-Macaulay ring (Q. m) of dimension d and an mprimary ideal q such that e (q) is negative. W e use the arguements given in [1] to obtain explicit values of the normalized Hilbert coefficients and use them subsequently to test our examples for the claim made above. To give a general treatment we must introduce some auxilliary notations which are explained at the appropriate place. Throughout this note (Q. m) denotes a Cohen-Macaulay ring with infinite residue field.

title: Effects of deployment schemes and out-of-plane librations on tethered payload raising
author: K Kumar and AK Misra and Rajeeva Kumar
abstract: Raising a payload by deploying it from an orbiter on a long tether and then releasing it represents a rather important application involving significant fuel economy. The effects of various deployment schemes as well as out-of-plane librations on tethered payload raising are systematically studied. Equations of motion have been obtained for a general two-body dumb-bell tethered system in an elliptic orbit executing the three-dimensional librational motion. This analysis accounts for the tether mass as well. Contrary to the observations made by Kyroudis and Conway. an increase in deployment rate does not lead to a monotonic increase in apogee altitude of the payload at release. Typical plots of the altitude gain vs deployment rate are presented showing widely differing and separated'peaks' and'valleys'. These could be used to select the optimum deployment scheme for raising payloads to higher altitudes. Finally …

title: Diabetic non diabetic maculopathy-A new entity
author: Rajvardhan Azad and Atul Kumar and HK Tewari
abstract: Classical forms of diabetic maculopathy are well-known. We observed various macular pathologies in the form of macular stippling. retinal pigment epithelial defects. colloids & disciform lesions all in NIDDM patients. 70% of whom were uncontrolled on therapy. These patients did not present with any of the classical changes suggestive of diabetic retinopathy. and we have grouped them as cases with'Diabetic Non-Diabetic Maculopathy'-DNDM.

title: Development and Strength of Polymer Composite Reinforced With Bamboo Fibres.(Retroactive Coverage)
author: S Jain and R Kumar and UC Jindal
abstract: Epoxy resin was reinforced with bamboo fibres and bamboo fibre mattings. so as to develop a bamboo fibre reinforced plastic (BFRP) composite with multidirectional and biaxial strength with a volume fraction (V sub f ) as high as 85-90%. BFRP composites with multidirectional reinforcement by fibres and two dimensional reinforcement by bamboo mattings have been developed using the simple casting technique and tested for various strengths. The tensile. impact and flexural strengths achieved for BFRP composites are 110.5 MNm exp --2 . 34.02 kJm exp --2 and 104.1 MNm exp --2 . respectively. for a fibre volume fraction of 85%. Moreover. these composites possess a ductile mechanical behaviour. The maximum tensile. impact and flexural strengths for natural fibres reinforced plastic (NFRP) composites reported so far are 104.0 MNm exp --2 (jute--epoxy). 22.0 kJm exp --2 (jute--polyester) and 64.0 MNm exp --2 …

title: Hormonal changes from birth to maturity in buffaloes.
author: R Kumar and PJS Rattan
journal: Hormonal changes from birth to maturity in buffaloes.
abstract: The low reproductive efficiency of the domestic buffalo (Bubalus bubalus Subject Category: Organism Namessee more details bubalis) is a major impediment in its milk production performance world-wide. Most of the reproductive disorders are of endocrinological origin. There is a scarcity of literature on hormonal changes during different developmental stages. In view of this the present study was undertaken. Investigations were conducted on apparently healthy Murrah buffalo heifers during different developmental and reproductive stages. Various hormones were quantified by standard radioimmunoassay techniques. Plasma oestradiol-17β level was comparatively high in postnatal calves. significantly low in young calves and max.. 26.06±3.69 pg/ml. in sexually mature heifers. Plasma progesterone progesterone Subject Category: Chemicals and Chemical Groups

title: Absorption spectrum of Cu2+ ions doped in ammonium aluminium sulphate single crystal
author: BC Venkata Reddy and B Sasikala Devi and B Munibhadrayya and R Rama Kumar
abstract: The absorption spectra of copper-doped ammonium aluminium sulphate single crystals were determined both at room and liquid-nitrogen temperature. The spectrum recorded at room temperature consists of four bands. When the crystal is cooled to liquid-nitrogen temperature. changes in the intensities of the bands are observed. From the magnitude and relative position of the bands. a successful interpretation of all the observed bands has been made and identified as those belonging to Cu2+ ion in octahedral symmetry. The crystal field and tetragonal field parameters are derived. The observed and calculated energies are in good agreement.

title: Electronic absorption spectrum of Co2+ ions doped in potassium dihydrogen phosphate single crystal
author: BC Venkata Reddy and R Rama Kumar
abstract: Single crystals of Potassium dihydrogen phosphate doped with Co2+ ions were grown by slow evaporation at room temperature from a saturated solution of Potassium dihydrogen phosphate to which 0.5 mole percent of Cobalt phosphate was added as an impurity. Electronic absorption spectra have been recorded at room and liquid nitrogen temperatures on Cary – 2390 Spectrophotometer. When the crystal is cooled to liquid nitrogen temperature. changes in intensity and band position are observed and some of the bands are splitted. From the nature and position of the bands. a successful interpretation of all the observed bands have been made and identified as those belonging to Co2+ ion in an octahedral crystal field. The crystal field parameters derived for room temperature are Dq = 860 cm−1. B = 920 cm−l and C = 3680 cm−1 and for liquid nitrogen temperature are Dq = 870 cm−l. B = 920 cm−1. C …

title: Metallographic Studies of Degenerative Mechanism in Fossil Fuel Fired Boiler Tubes
author: R Kumar and GG Nair and SP Mukherjee
abstract: Boiler tubes. exposed periodically to higher temperature excursions over the designed temperature. undergo accelerated structural degradation. often the cause of unscheduled outages at large thermal power plants. Reviewed with the help of metallographic investigations are some of the operative degenerative mechanisms. illustrated with specific examples of boiler tube bursts. The frequency of such failures is aggravated when the boiler is operating under condition of fluctuating load. especially when high ash pulverizing fuel coal is used. Presented is an interesting case study by using metallographic evidence of structural degeneration and growth of oxide film. It has been possible to provide an estimate of the extent of cumulative damage caused by both temperature and time (in mild steel). Graphs. photomicrographs. 1 ref.--AA

title: Degeneration Mechanism in Economiser Tubes in Boilers Fired With High Ash Indian Coals
author: R Kumar and GG Nair and AK Singh
journal: Fossil Power Plant Rehabilitation: Trends in Life Management and Reliability Technology
abstract: Apart from its high content. ash of Indian coal is regarded as highly abrasive. After reviewing salient features of fly ash obtained through studies involving the use of X-ray diffraction. SEM and particle size analyser. metallographic evidence of the degeneration of the economiser tubes. which is shown to occur through impactation and cold work. is provided. Since it has often been suggested that beneficiation of coal provides a method for reducing the erosive loss of metal in the economiser tubes. the results of beneficiation coals on the constitution and morphology of fly ash are preserved. The results are discussed from the point of view of anticipating their effects on the loss of metals (mild steel). Graphs. photomicrographs. 4 ref.--AA

title: Pressure Drop as a Tool for Anticipating Boiler Tube Bursts
author: R Kumar
abstract: An attempt is made to critically analyse the operational behaviour of three boiler units of 100/110/210 MW thermal power stations in terms of the pressure drop between the boiler drum and the superheater outlet with a view to provide a system's approach for understanding the operational factors which might have a bearing on boiler tube failures in the superheater circuit. Presented are the results of statistical analysis of actual performance of three boiler units and they are summarised in the shape of a triangle of performance indicating the latitude of the fluctuation of pressure drop within safe limits. When the boiler operates with thermal conditions such that the pressure drop is outside the limits of safe operation. the net outcome is that the environment around the tube becomes more aggressive in terms of increase in temperature and pressure and their transients. Also provided is sufficient evidence to show that …

title: Structure. Stability and Thermodynamics of Liquid Base Binary Alloys
author: CS Sivaramakrishnan and R Kumar
journal: International Conference on Base Metals Technology
abstract: Various factors that influence the structure and stability of binary liquid Pb alloys are discussed. Size factor. electronegativities and thermodynamic functions of the Pb-solute systems have been discussed and the concept of incipient immiscibility has been brought out. The behaviour of solutions has also been related to the nature of phase diagrams. The results of centrifuging studies of Pb alloys. Pb--17Cd. Pb--30Cd. Pb--38Cd. Pb--10Sb. Pb--17Sb. Pb--77Sb. Pb--87Sb. Pb--87Sn. carried out at the National Metallurgical Laboratory have been shown. It has been established that like or unlike atom clustering exists in liquid Pb alloys. Graphs. phase diagrams. 31 ref.--AA

title: Recent Technological Developments in Aluminum Melt Treatment for Direct Chill Casting
author: CS Sivaramakrishnan and RK Mahanti and R Kumar
journal: Journal of the Institution of Engineers(India), Metallurgy and Material Science
abstract: Some indigenous developments in the area of melt treatment for continuous/semi-continuous casting of Al and its alloys are discussed. A novel technique of degassing through a microporous diffuser. the development of a special filter medium and inoculant for continuous grain refinement are described. These developments enable production of cleaner melt free from dissolved gases. inclusions and sodium. Graphs. 32 ref.--D.J.K.(Alfed).

title: Early Detection of ras Oncogenes Activated by Chemical Carcinogentreatment
author: R Kumar and S Sukumar and M Barbacid
abstract: Molecular analysis of H-ras oncogenes induced by a single dose of nitrosomethylurea (NMU) in pubescent rats revealed their consistent activation by G→A transitions. the type of mutation preferentially induced by NMU. These results suggested that NMU is directly responsible for the malignant activation of ras oncogenes during initiation of carcinogenesis. We have now modified this experimental system to examine’ the precise mechanisms by which ras oncogenes contribute to carcinogenesis. Our results suggest that although ras oncogenes may become activated during the carcinogenic insult. they require specific cooperation with normal developmental programs to exert their carcinogenic properties. Definitive demonstration of this hypothesis requires identification of activated ras oncogenes in the putative target cells prior to the manifestation of the neoplastic phenotype. In an attempt to reach the …

title: FETAL AND NEONATAL DEVELOPMENT OF RAT
author: RATAN KUMAR and BN CHAUDHURI
abstract: Influence of maternal thyroid status on fetal and neonatal development of rats has been studied. Maternal hypothyroidism resulted impaired reproduction and intrauterine growth retardation of offsprings as revealed by their reduced body weight. heart weight. body length and tail length. Offsprings born to hypothyroid mothers showed very high rate of mortality and none of them survived beyond eight days.. Maternal hyperthyrodism did not cause any abnormality on reproduction. Hyperthyroid mothers showed increased rate in body weight gain during pregnancy which was associated with increased weight of body and heart of fetuses born to hyperthyroid mothers. Plasma thyroxine was not measurable in fetus from hypothyroid mothers till 21st day of gestation. The results of the present study showed that maternal thyroid'status plays an important role in fetal and neonatal growth and development.

title: ZEOLITE BETA: A SUITABLE CATALYST FOR ISOMERIZATION AND HYDROCRACKING OF LONG CHAIN n-ALKANES
author: S ERNST and R KUMAR and J WEITKAMP
journal: Catalysis, Concepts and Applications: Proceedings of the Ninth National Symposium on Catalysis, December 15-17, 1988
abstract: Zeolite Beta was synthesized. brought into a bifunctional form and tested as a catalyst in isomerization and hydrocracking of selected long chain n-alkanes. The product distributions (as exemplified with n-undecane as feed) exhibit some similarities with those obtained earlier on bifunctional Y-type zeolites. However. considerably higher yields of feed isomers could be obtained with 0. 27 wt.-% Pd/HBeta. Therefore. this catalyst seems to be well suited for improving the low temperature properties of distillates by isomerization of the waxy components. Results of supplementary catalytic experiments involving the comparative conversion of four Cg-alkanes with different degrees of branching strongly suggest that hydrocracking in zeolite Beta proceeds ma inly via the energetically most favorable type A B-scissions. Since they start from bulky intermediates. it can be concluded that the suppression of hydrocracking reactions in zeolite Beta is not due to shape selectivity effects.

title: Improving access to MCH care facilities within existing health infrastructure
author: VIJAY Kumar and S Singhi and R Kumar and NEENA Raina
abstract: PIP: To improve maternal-child services (MCH) services within existing health infrastructures. an operational project was initiated in district Ambala. Haryana. in northern India in February 1985. The main project strategies are training of primary health care (PHC) workers. logistic improvement. and monitoring. This paper reports on the 1st year of project operation and deals with the changes in availability of MCH care facilities. Before and after surveys were undertaken in a sample of 71 and 74 villages. respectively. across 3 blocks of the intervention area (population=370.000). 62 villages from 2 adjacent blocks (population=250.000) were also surveyed at the same time as the after survey; these served as concurrent controls. The information was collected from the village leaders and healthworkers by trained fieldworkers. The villages in intervention area registered a substantial improvement in availability of oral …

author: R Nagaraj and Sebastian Morris and Anusua Bhattacharjee and Geeta Gouri and Usha Ramachandra and R Nandagopal and M Jayadev and VG Sudhakar Reddy and G Satyanarayana and Ranjani and G Sudha and K Srinivas and I Mallikarjuna Sharma and Rita Mukherjee and Alice Morris and G Vijaya Kumar and R Radhakrishna and Prama Hanuman and KV Anjaneyu and SV Krishna Mohan and A Surendra Raju and S Ramachandra Rao and S Venkatasubbaiah and Irfan Habib and Ravinder Kumar and Upendra Baxi and DN Jha and Sumit Sarkar and Harbans Mukhia and Bipan Chandra and Mushirul Hasan and GP Deshpande and Geeta Kapur and Vivan Sundaram and Suresh Sharma and Rajiv Kumar and Anuradha Kapur and Prabhat Patnaik and Krishna Bharadwaj and Utsa Patnaik and Zoya Hasan and Sudipto Kaviraj and Sabyasachi Bhattacharya and Neeladri Bhattacharya and Aparna Basu and Arundhati Virmani and Monica Juneja and KM Shrimali and Shahid Amin and Gyanendra Pandey and Ashish Banerji and Kumkum Sangari and Tanika Sarkar and Uma Chakravarti and Purushottam Agarwal and Dilip Simeon and Chitra Joshi and Pragati Mahapatra and Vasudha Pande and Sanjay Sharma and Rana Behl and Anil Sethi and Kapil Kumar
abstract: The main contention of Mehta in this-'article is that historians have to distinguish between facts and myth while studying social processes. He argues that traditional historians in Gujarat have used folk customs and idioms to explain contemporary social customs and traditions. They have maintained written and oral cultural and literary traditions of Gujarat. For them facts. as modern day historians understand them. did not have as much importance as mysterious cyclical historical eve4its. Mehta further says that though new sects and saints. as also political conflict. occasionally disturbed social equilibrium. social forces again got reinstated. resulting in. the maintenance of the status quo. The Swaminarayan sect is not an exemption to this tradition. The purpose of the article is to examine the Swaminarayan literature in its social context in order to exemplify its basic theoretical position. Mehta uses both primary and …

title: Probing the Shape Selective Properties of Zeolites ZSM-12 and EU-1 by Catalytic Test Reactions
author: R Kumar and S Ernst and GT Kokotailo and J Weitkamp
abstract: The shape selective properties of zeolites ZSM-12 and EU-1 were evaluated by means of a variety of catalytic hydrocarbon reactions (hydrocracking of butyl-cyclohexane. isomerization and hydrocracking of n-decane and n-dodecane. disproportionation of ethyl benzene). The results show that a precise classification of the pore width of EU-1 is difficult: Some probe reactions indicate that its effective pore width is between those of ZSM-5 and ZSM-12 while others point to an effective pore width slightly above that of ZSM-12. Perhaps. the void structure of zeolite EU-1 consists of both 10-membered ring channels and a second channel or cavity system formed by puckered 12-membered rings.

title: Electronic absorption spectrum of Mn2+ ions doped in ammonium perchlorate single crystal
author: BC Venkata Reddy and B Munibhadraiah and I Aruna Kumari
abstract: The absorption spectrum of Mn2+ ions doped in ammonium perchlorate has been studied. The observed bands are assigned as transitions from the 6Alg(S) ground state to various excited quartet states of Mn2+ ion in octahedral symmetry. The observed band positions are fitted with four parameters B. C. Dq and α and the best fit is obtained with B = 800 cm−1. C = 3150 cm−1. Dq = 800 cm−1 and α = 76 cm−1.

title: GALACTOMANNAN FROM CASSIA MARGINATA SEEDS–METHYLATION AND PERIODATE OXIDATION STUDIES
author: Rajiv KUMAR and Km Anjani SINGHAL and UK JINDAL
abstract: Rozpuszczalny w wodzie galaktomannan otrzymany z nasion Cassia marginata tworzy w wyniku hydrolizy D-galaktozę i D-mannozę w sto-sunku molowym 1: 4. Hydroliza metylowanego galaktomannanu prowadzi do 2. 3. 4. 6-tetra-O-metylo-Dg alaktozy (1 mol). 2. 3. 6-tri-O-metylo-D-mannozy (3 mole) i. 2. 3-di-O-metylo-D-mannozy (1 mol). Podczas utleniania (1. 5 nadjodanu na jednostkę hydroheksozy) powstaje mol kwasu mrówkowego na pięć jednostek anhydroheksozy. Na tej podstawie przypisano galaktomannanowi budowę 1.The water soluble galactomannan from Cassia marginata seeds on hydrolysis yields D-galactose and D-mannose in a molar ratio of 1: 4. Hydrolysis of the methylated galactomannan affords 2. 3. 4. 6-tetra-O--methyl-D-galactose (1 mole). 2. 3. 6-tri-O-methyl-D-mannose (3 mole) and 2. 3-di-O-methyl-D-mannose (1 mole). On oxidation it consumes 1.5 of periodate for each an hydrohexose unit with the liberation of one mole of formic acid for each five anhydrohexose units. Based on these results a tentative structure 1 has been assigned to galactomannan.

title: SALT CONSUMPTION PATTERN IN THE RURAL AND URBAN AREAS OF ROHTAK (HARYANA). INDIA
author: Rakesh Kumar and DR Gaur and Vidya Prakash Sood and AK Sood and Sunder Lai
abstract: The salt is the cheapest and most easily available commodity in the country. However. the findings relate to the salt consumption pattern in the urban and rural areas of Rohtak (Haryana) suggest that the iodized salt was not easily available for the masses in the study area. per unit daily consumption of salt varied from 9 to 14 grams. Government may subsidize the price of iodized salt and ensure a better system for its distribution. etc.Iodine Deficiency Disorders (IDD) are highly prevalent in India. Fifteen States (out of 22) and five Union Territories (out of 9) are endemic for IDD'. The iodization of salt for human consumption in the endemic areas has been found to be the most effective. economical. feasible and acceptable as compared to injection of iodated oil and addition of iodine to drinking water2. Although. the National Goitre Control Programme has supplied the iodized salt in the endemic areas. yet the desired …

title: Decompression sickness after exercise at 4. 572 m(15. 000 ft)- A case report
author: M AKHTAR and P TYAGI and RANJIT KUMAR and KV KUMAR and N MADAN
abstract: Decompression sickness in aviation is usually encountered at altitudes above 9144 m. This paper presents a case of bends which occurred at a simulated altitude of 4572 m in a hypobaric chamber following accidental decompression during submaximal treadmill exercise. It is suggested that even moderately severe exercise at low altitudes may predispose healthy subjects breathing air to decompression sickness. (Author)

abstract: Parainfectious Encephalomyelitis (PE) is a striking neurologica! syndrome which may follow common childhood xanthems. eg Rubeola. The pathogenesis of this condition appears to be immunologically mediated. In this report seven children (mean age 5.6 years) with. a neurological disorder consistent with PE are described. Most had a non-specific illness preceding the onset of neurological symptoms and signs. The evolution of the disorder was slow'in 6 patients and findings indicatedl consistent involvement of sub-cortical white matter in all. Three patients treated with cortico-steroids exhibited dramatic response with rapid resolution. of signs and symptoms. All of the children recovered but some had neurological sequelae including behavioral and developmental disorders (1). generalised hyperreflexia and extensor plantar responses (1) and optic atrophy (3). The relationship between this condition and multiple …

title: Use Of CT Computer In Other Radiological Applications
author: Rajendra Kumar
abstract: A method has been developed to use the CT-1010 EMI scanner computer as a general purpose computer. The Main purpose of the work was to develop the method so that CT computer can be used more effectively for non-CT application also without affecting the CT software and CT image data in any manner. The RDOS general operation system has been installed on the same disc as EMI software. Care has been taken to make sure that RDOS remains compatible to the RTOs operating System on which the EMI software is based. Application software for patient data recording and analysis and also for X-ray film inventory has been developed and tested by making use of RDOS operating system. The Software developed for patient data recording can record directly on magnetic tape. the patient name. age. sex. x-ray number and disease code etc. This data can then be used by another program which can sort it …

title: A New Method For Designing The Parallel Square Hole Gamma Camera Collimator
author: Rajendra Kumar and GS Pant
abstract: It has been observed by one of us that the detection of a cold lesion of a given size is easier if it is located in larger organ (with radioactive distribution) than in a smaller organ provided the contrast is high enough. This type of dependence of detect ability of cold lesion has not been incorporated in the design of gamma camera collimator. In this paper we have attempted to develop the theory for designing the parallel square whole gamma camera collimator. The method takes into account the size of the cold area and of the surrounding hot area in the organ. The associated problems in the design have been discussed and usefulness of an image processing device; so-called collywobbler has been investigated.

title: Design and construction of gates for small scale hydropower.
author: G Chauhan and A Kumar and PK Jain
abstract: Design and construction of gates for small scale hydro power projects (SHP) warrant a departure from conventional approach used for large hydro power projects. While fail-safe operation of the gates is vital for successful functioning of both. the large as well as small hydro power projects. there is a wide difference in terms of cost of gates when expressed as a percentage of total project cost. The cost of gates constitute a low percentage of total project cost in large hydro power projects and the emphasis has been on safe and proper functioning of the gates with little attention to their cost. In SHP. however. the gates constitute a relatively higher percentage of total project cost and hence their design and construction has to be low in cost commensurate with safety and functional requirements. This paper reports the design and construction aspects of gates suitable for SHP on the basis of experimental study carried out …

title: Some Observations on Anticipating the Remaining Life of Service Exposed Steam Pipes in Thermal Power Plants
author: RN Ghosh and R Singh and R Kumar
abstract: Remaining lives of several service exposed steam pipes collected from thermal power plants have been evaluated through accelerated stress rupture tests. The results have been analysed using the most commonly used parametric methods. This revealed that the expected life calculated on the basis of the lower cut off point. representing a confidence level of 97.5%. does not agree well with the extent of service exposure of the respective tubes. However. their predicted 100 000 h rupture strength does show a definite trend with the length of service. though the expected lives were in the range of 50 000-100 000 h. Microstructural examinatoin did not show any significant accumulation of creep damage. As 100 000 h rupture strength was significantly higher than the design requirement of 45 MPa. it was concluded that these were fit for further use. 5 ref.--AA

title: The physiology of dihydroxylated vitamin D3 metabolites in man and experimental animals
author: R Kumar
abstract: EHDP is known to suppress kidney 25 (0H) D.-l-hydroxylase and to inhibit bone formation. In an attempt to establish whether post renal impairment of vitamin D metabolism occurs due to treatment with EHDP. chicks were depleted of vitamin D and were repleted with 1. 25 (OH). D3 as their sole source of the vrtamin. The chicks were then divided Into 2 groups. one being treated with EHDP while the second group served as control. The intestinal absorption of calcium in the EHDP-treated group was found to be impaired along with reduction in concentrations of CaBP. When the chicks were dosed with 3H-1. 25 (OH). D.. significantly lower concentrations of the sterol were detected in duodena of EHDP-treated birds. Measurement of levels of receptors for 1. 25 (OH). D3 In duodena showed no difference between groups. but levels of 1. 25 (OH). D. in sera were considerably lower In the EHDP-treated group along with …

title: Survivorship for some breeds of bovine in Punjab
author: TB Jain and UG Nadkarni and R Kumar
abstract: Survivorship measures viability of the species in different environments. The survivors (1x) to any age x from a given cohort depend on the mean length of life of the species. For comparison of survivorship of bovines of different breeds. percentage deviations for mean length of life are first obtained. The curves drawn for survivorship against these percentage deviations for Hariana. Sahiwal and nondescript breeds of the cattle and Murrah. Nili and nondescript breeds of buffaloes found in ICD and non-ICD areas of Punjab are discussed

title: Electric Grade and Aluminum Alloy Conductors--Recent Developments.(Retroactive Coverage)
author: R Kumar
journal: The Second Arab Aluminium Conference. Arabal 85
abstract: Although the use of Al. either as steel reinforced Al conductor (ACSR) or all Al conductor (AAC) has been universally accepted. Al alloy conductors as all Al alloy conductor (AAAC) and alloy reinforced Al conductor (ACAR) are gaining increasing applications on their technological merits as a result of sustained metallurgical studies and developments. The influence of various parameters such as metallurgical structure. temperature. solute concentration and lattice defects on the electrical conductivity is discussed. The developments of newer conductor materials. in view of stringent requirements besides good electrical conductivity. resistance to steady state creep and stress relaxation high yield and tensile strength low cycle fatigue resistance structural stability until higher than service temperature and corrosion resistance are described. National Metallurgical Laboratory (India) carried out extensive research in the …

title: Liquid State Treatment of Aluminum Alloy Melts.(Retroactive Coverage)
author: R Kumar and CS Sivaramakrishnan and RK Mahanti
journal: The Second Arab Aluminium Conference. Arabal 85
abstract: The role of the structure of liquid state in the development of desired properties on solidification is of great current interest. Results of studies on the structure of liquid metals aimed at establishing the existence of clusters and to focus the significance of their influence on the solidification process along with certain recent advances in melt treatment are summarized. These developments. with the increasing demand for quality products. have given great impact to innovations in the techniques of liquid state treatments like degassing. grain refinement and filtration. Casting from semi solid state has also acquired technological recognition as it holds potential for producing components with special properties. The above developments are discussed. with particular reference to National Metallurgical Laboratory's contribution in the respective areas. 26 ref.--D.J.K.(Alfed).

title: Aluminum Alloy Conductors
author: K Lal and R Kumar
abstract: India's intensive electrification programs will utilize NML-PM-215. a new Al--Mg--Si heat treatable alloy with better ductility. fatigue strength. corrosion resistance and tropical suitability. Electrical conductor material requirements and effects of alloying elements are discussed showing advantages of alloys over steel reinforced Al and their expanding applications. NML-PM-215 alloy description compares properties and power rating with other conductors and gives evaluation tests for four applications. 10 ref.--J.V.R.(US)*.

title: Studies on Corrosion Behavior of Some Aluminium Alloys for Collection of Polymetallic Nodules From Sea Bed
author: K Lal and I Singh and AK Bhattamishra and R Kumar
abstract: An imported alloy. Al Boomorang Grab. which had been used for metal nodule retrievement in the Indian Ocean was found to be similar in composition to IS4300 alloy. Because of corrosion problems with the grab. comparative corrosion tests were conducted on LM5 alloy (Al + 5% magnesium) and LM25 alloys. Based upon the results. LM5 appears to be a better alternative. Immersion studies and polorization tests were used and tables. figures and metallographic results are given. 4 ref.--J.C.J.

title: Infections by Proteus species in the subtropics: I.
author: J Grant and R Kumar
journal: IRCS Medical Science. Cell and Molecular Biology
abstract: Proteus isolations from clinical sources are most commonly associated with urinary tract disease. wound infections and chronic suppurative otitis media. The frequency of Proteus cultures from a wide range of clinical samples. however. testifies to its association with many other conditions. This article represents an attempt to record these proportions for the first time. and to seek characters which may have importance for the region. In addition. the relative proportions of isolations among other categories of disease were sought. as has been done for Enterobacteriaceae elsewhere.

title: Infections by Proteus species in the subtropics: II.
author: J Grabt and R Kumar
journal: IRCS Medical Science. Cell and Molecular Biology
abstract: Multiple infections are more problematic than others. In addition. estimates made concerning them are complicated by the many different techniques used in clinical microbiology. In view of the common occurrence of Proteus infections on the North African littoral. and the contributions to the laboratory workload which this represents. a study was made to gauge the frequency of concomitant bacterial pathogens which are so often observed with Proteus .

title: Simple tests in amniotic fluid for evaluation of gestational age
author: KL Srivastava and A Kumar and PK Misra and P Mehra and R Kaul
abstract: Amniotic fluid was collected from 105 pregnant mothers without any obstertrical or medical complications between 13–41 weeks of gestation. Simple tests viz. Nile blue sulphate test for cytology and shake test were performed in 92 cases.The study has revealed that more than 20 percent of orange cells were found above 36 weeks of gestation in most of the cases (92%) and the cells were in clusters. The shake test positive results increased with the increasing gestational age and were seen in majority of cases (82.5%) above 36 weeks of pregnancy.The cell was found to be a better parameter as compared to shake test. However. based on the results of study both the tests are recommended for routine use in ward side laboratories.

title: Personality needs associated with high and low scholastic achievement.
author: Rajiv Kumar
abstract: Studied high (HAs) and low achievers (LAs) with respect to 10 personality needs including autonomy. abasement. and aggression. From 248 male Intermediate College students. who were administered a personality inventory and whose scholastic achievement scores were available. 41 HAs and 25 LAs were selected for analysis of personality needs. Results show that LAs scored higher on the need for dominance. HAs scored higher on needs for endurance and nurturance. Exhibition and endurance were related to the scholastic achievement of HAs.(PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA. all rights reserved)

title: Enhancement of reactivity of HLA-Cw antisera by extending the incubation time.
author: DM Wong and R Kumar and KK Mittal
abstract: HLA-Cw antisera showing weak cytotoxic activity when tested at 1 1/2 hours in the conventional HLA-A. B. Cw testing procedure. were found to react better in the test using an extended incubation period of 3 hours. Of the 71 sera which were tested. 15 (21%) sera demonstrated an increase in anti-HLA-Cw reactivity against cells from donors possessing the corresponding Cw antigen. In addition. the use of B cells in the testing procedure appeared to be more favorable than T cells in the enhancement of reactivity of weak HLA-Cw antisera.

title: Note to Goto’s paper “Every noetherian uniformly coherent ring has dimension at most 2”
author: Ravinder Kumar and Jun-ichi Nishimura
journal: Journal of Mathematics of Kyoto University
abstract: Let A be a commutative ring with unity. A is said to be coherent if every finitely generated ideal of A is finitely presented. A is said to be uniformly coherent if there is a function so: N su ch th at for each n E N and any A-homomorphism f: A" A. Ker f is generated by at most 99 (n) elements. The notion of uniform coherence was introduced by Soublin [9] and subsequently studied by many authors including Goto [4]. Quentel [7] and Sally [8]. Sally [8] proved that a local ring is uniformly coherent if its (Krull) dimension is at most two. Goto [4] sharpened this result and proved that the converse also holds. ie.

author: SB Beri and KB Bhalla and R Bhanja
publisher: Lund Univ.(Sweden). Dept. of Cosmic and Subatomic Physics
abstract: Cosmic ray based-and recent accelerator basei? heavy ion 2-4) fragmentation experiments have given-some indications of an anomalous component which has an extremely large reaction probability and a long enough lifetime to produce collisions separated in space from the primary interaction. Speculations about the origin of this component range from quark-gluon effects 7—8) via normal nuclear physics effects to quasi-molecular effects'.

title: EVALUATION OF VARIOUS LABORATORY TECHNIQUES USED FOR RABIES DIAGNOSIS
author: Ram Kumar and ML Mehrotra
abstract: The diagnosis of rabies is of paramount importance. Various methods viz. Seller's rapid staining. histopathology. fluorescent antibody (FA) technique and biological test in laboratory animals are advocated for its diagnosis (2). Most of the laboratories commonly practise first two procedures due to limited laboratory facilities and non-availability of suitable materials (3. 4). In the present communication. all the four methods were attempted and assessed for precise and quick diagnosis of rabies. These techniques were taken up according to the avaijable materials from field. Most of the time complete materials for all the 4 tests were not available.Thirty six specimens of different species of animals from different parts of the country formed the materials of this study. Heads of 23 cases suspected for rabies were received. while 2 specimens in 10 per cent formalin and 5 in 50 per cent buffered glycerine were obtained for histopathological examina-tion and biological test. respectively. When the heads of suspected cases were received. two to three impression smears were prepared from hippocampus. cerebellum and medulla. Impression smears were stained with Seller's stain (5). These were exposed to UV light before examination under oil immersion lens.

title: Surgical experience with Aneurysm of the Sinus of Valsalva
author: KS Neelakandhan and R Sankar Kumar and MS Valiathan
journal: Indian Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery
abstract: During a three year period from July 1977 to July 1980. six cases of Aneurysm of the Sinus of Valsalva underwent surgical correction in our Institute. Three of them were males and three females. The constant symptoms were palpitations and fatigability and the constant signs were collapsing pulse and continuous murmur with thrill. In four cases the right coronary sinus had ruptured into the right ventricular outflow; in two patients. the non-coronary sinus was involved. one rupturing into the right atrium. the other one being unruptured. Four patients had associated aortic regurgitation and two had ventricular septal defect. All were corrected surgically; four patients with aortic regurgitation had aortic valve replacement; the ventricular septal defects were closed directly. One patient died on the operating table; one died at home suddenly. two months after surgery. The other four patients are doing well clinically …

title: Fission-product source terms measured during fuel-damage tests in the Power Burst Facility.[PWR; BWR]
author: DJ Osetek and JJ King and RM Kumar
publisher: EG and G Idaho. Inc.. Idaho Falls (USA)
abstract: Fission-product release from light-water-reactor-type fuel rods to the coolant was measured during eight fuel damage tests in the Power Burst Facility. On-line gamma spectroscopic measurements of short-lived fission products. and important aspects of fission product behavior observed during the tests. are discussed. The fission-product source terms were found to be very time-dependent. requiring 1 to 3 hours for equilibrium levels to be established. Estimates of the release rate constants generated during certain tests are provided. A comparison is made between calculated and measured release signatures for selected isotopes. Iodine behavior is discussed. and fuel fracturing is identified as a strong release mechanism that may substantially contribute to fission product source terms during light-water-reactor accidents where the core is damaged but the fuel does not melt.

title: On the damping effect of sloshing fluid on flexible rotor systems
author: MK GHOSH and PC UPADHYAYA and A KUMAR
journal: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Design and Production Engineering Technical Conference, Washington, DC
abstract: Results of an experimental investigation on the vibration attenuation characteristics of a free liquid sloshing in a rigid container are reported for a flexible rotor on a flexible foundation. Attenuation of the vibrational amplitude of the foundation is markedly seen in the experimental results. Free liquid sloshing in rigid containers can become an effective means of limiting vibration amplitude at resonances below 15 c.p.s.

title: Ectiban and Diazinon Pour-ON Treatments for Control of Lice on Beef Cattle. 1981
author: JE Lloyd and R Kumar and C Jones
abstract: Experimental cattle were either Hereford or mixed breeds. and originated at several locations in eastern WY. All animals were heifer calves or yearling heifers. Experimental groups of from 5-12 animals were housed in separate dry lots at University of Wyoming Livestock Units at Torrington and Cheyenne. WY. Ectiban 1% pour-on was applied at 0.5 oz/100 lb body weight along the backline. Diazinon AG500 was applied in a single spot on the back at 2.5 or 1.25 cc/100 lb. Cattle were treated once with the exception of 1 group at Torrington that was treated a second time with Ectiban pour-on. Weather conditions at time of treatments were favorable. i.e.. temperatures between 20 and 44°F and no precipitation immediately following treatment. All cattle were inspected for lice prior to treatment. then at various times post-treatment. Total numbers of lice were recorded in the inspection areas which were 1. 15 cm hair …

title: Impact of Research at NML(National Metallurgical Laboratory) on the Aluminum Technology in India
author: R Kumar
abstract: For electrical conductor EC-grade Al lacks adequate ductility at acceptable levels of tensile strength and cold flow occurs at crimp joints; development of NML-PM2 alloy is discussed. Indian standards for EC-grade Al were widened to include the alloy. Use of NML-PM2 in overhead transmission lines. telecommunication and railway signaling cable and electrical machinery is summarized. Joint stability is considered. To replace Al--0.5Mg--0.5Si. another alloy. NML-PM215. was developed with a 51% IACS electrical conductivity at a tensile strength of 28-30 kg/mm exp 2 but with considerably higher ductility. The corrosion resistance is of the order of D-50S. Work to improve the quality of Al utensils includes recommendations regarding fluxing and inoculants. Qualities of a reactive filter developed are given.--EAA/AF.

title: On the role of irrigation frequences on the regrowth of berseem [clover. India]
author: A Kumar and SD Rai

title: A study of family background. intellectual ability of educationally advantaged & disadvantaged groups.
author: Govind Tewari and Km Roma Pal and Rakesh Kumar
abstract: 100 high and 100 low academic achievers. selected from a sample of 350 secondary school students. completed a family relations inventory and an intelligence test. High achievers received more acceptance from fathers and less parental avoidance than did low achievers. Parental concentration on the S promoted educational deprivation by failing to provide a family atmosphere conducive to achievement. Educationally nondeprived Ss scored higher than deprived Ss on both verbal and nonverbal intelligence.(7 ref)(PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA. all rights reserved)

title: Evaluation of prompt release of fission gas from a breached cladding.[PWR; BWR]
author: MS El-Genk and RM Kumar
publisher: EG and G Idaho. Inc.. Idaho Falls (USA)
abstract: It is a concern in the current safety analysis of nuclear reactors to understand the different release mechanisms of fission products to accurately determine the radiological source term for a wide variety of accidents. The mechanism which is least understood and which produces an uncertainty in determining the radiological source term during a reactor accident is the early release of fission gas present in the fuel-cladding gap through a cladding breach. In a loss-of-coolant type accident the fuel rods would be surrounded mainly by steam. therefore. the release of the gap gas can simply be treated as a discharge problem through an orifice. However. during reactor normal operation or in those accidents where the failed fuel rods are surrounded by liquid coolant. the release process of the gap gas would be strongly influenced by the coolant conditions (pressure. temperature and flow rate). The purpose of this work is to describe analytically the prompt escape of volatiles and gaseous fission products. present in the fuel-cladding gap through a cladding breach. where the fuel rod is surrounded by liquid coolant.

title: An evaluation of prompt release of fission gas from a breached cladding

title: Resignation-frustration and sex as correlates of interest modality among dropouts' and non-dropouts' parents.
author: Govind Tiwari and K Kiran Morbhatt and MC Jain and Rakesh Kumar
abstract: Studied the simultaneous effects of resignation and sex by a multivariate factorial design. Ten males and 10 females. evenly divided between being resigned and nonresigned as determined by a resignation test. who were parents of dropout and nondropout male students served as Ss. They completed Chatterji's Non-Language Preference Record. Form 962. The factors of Resignation and Sex were then correlated with interest in the fine arts. literature. science. medicine. and agriculture. Nondropout Ss showed a significantly higher interest in science than dropout Ss. This may be due to the inability of dropout Ss to cope with modern scientific developments. Females were found to be more interested in agriculture than males. probably due to females' increased consciousness in agricultural dealings.(9 ref)(PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA. all rights reserved)

title: TRANS4: a computer code calculation of solid fuel penetration of a concrete barrier.[LMFBR; GCFR]
author: CM Ono and R Kumar and JK Fink
abstract: The computer code. TRANS4. models the melting and penetration of a solid barrier by a solid disc of fuel following a core disruptive accident. This computer code has been used to model fuel debris penetration of basalt. limestone concrete. basaltic concrete. and magnetite concrete. Sensitivity studies were performed to assess the importance of various properties on the rate of penetration. Comparisons were made with results from the GROWS II code.

title: A Sojourn Into the Field of Fracture Toughness in Aluminum Alloys
author: CS Sivaramakrishnan and R Kumar
abstract: The basic factors involved in different stages of crack growth in metals. the concept of fracture toughness and its measurement are reviewed. The factors particularly affecting fracture toughness and crack initiation and growth in Al alloys are discussed. Effect of sheet thickness. initial mechanical properties. environmental conditions and actual loading conditions will vary for different alloys. and data are given for typical examples. Unlike ferrous materials which become brittle at cryogenic temperature. Al alloys show good ductility and increased strength. Tabulated data on a large number of standard alloys show improvement in fracture toughness down to -- 250 deg C.32 refs.--M.R.

title: Effect of Two-Phase Solidification on the Aging Kinetics of Al-- Cu and Al-- Zn-- Mg Alloys
author: RK Mahanti and CS Sivaramakrishnan and R Kumar
abstract: Two-phase solidification (TPS) produces grain refinement in the cast morphology of Al -- 4.4Cu. Al -- 4.4Cu -- 0.25Mg and Al -- 5.6Zn -- 1.25Mg alloys containing 1% Li. It accelerates the precipitation process and maintains the peak values for longer periods as compared to conventional casting. The effect of TPS is most pronounced in Al -- Cu -- Mg -- Li alloys followed by Al -- Cu -- Li and Al -- Zn -- Mg -- Li. Solution treatment temperature influences the aging kinetics. higher temperatures produce faster aging.24 refs.--AA*.

title: Development of Indigenous Technology for Aluminum Alloy Filler Wires
author: R Kumar and BK Saxena and GD Sani and PK De
abstract: Indian technology for the production of Al -- 5% Mg filler wire /rods corresponding to BS 2901 NG6 and IS:1278. 1972 NG6 and Al -- 5% Cu filler wire corresponding to HAL Specification MS RR 9500/34 has been established. The filler wires/rods so produced are in use at Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd.. and have been found to satisfy all the rigid specifications. The two grades of filler wires have now been designated as NML-PM6 and NML-PM7 filler wires. respectively.11 refs.--AA*.

title: Development of Aluminum/Aluminum Alloy Conductors for Electrical Industries
author: R Kumar and M Singh and K Lal
abstract: In view of the limitations of EC grade Al alloys. some new alloys have been developed and are designated versatile electric grade Al alloy NML-PM2; medium-conductivity medium-strength alloy NML-PM53 and high-strength medium-conductivity alloy NML-PM215. The characteristics and properties of these alloys are given. NML-PM2 is being used for welding cable. PVC-insulated and sheathed flexible cable. overhead conductors. power transformers and enameled magnet wire. In an alternative composition (NML-PM53) conductivity is reduced with a substantial increase in tensile strength. NML-PM215 is used for grooved contact wire. A heat treatable Al wire is also under development as a substitute for Si -- Mn steel in current collector strip.6 refs.--M.R.

title: Influence of Metallurgical and Processing Factors on the Stress Corrosion Susceptibility of Welded Al--Zn--Mg Alloys
author: BK Saxena and L Lal and R Kumar
abstract: Factors affecting weld-metal susceptibility are considered. Effects of composition of weld metal and heat affected zone. composition and grain structure of parent metal. processing parameters of extrusions and welding conditions are discussed. The presence of coarse recrystallized grains at the weld/parent-metal interface and segregation of Zn at the grain boundary in weld pool have been observed by optical microscopy and SEM. and these resistance to SCC. Measures recommended include maintenance of a fibrous structure. selection of suitable homogenization and hot working temperature. and use of a duplex post-weld aging treatment with the second step producing overaging. A suitable filler composition and welding technique should be selected. and weld bead width kept to a minimum.19 refs.--EPAA/AF.

title: Effect of chlorpromazine on salmonella antibody synthesis in man
author: KC Singhal and R Kumar and Singhal Usha
abstract: . Forty healthy individuals and 70 psychiatric patients aged 25 to 45 years without previous history of TAB inoculation or enteric fever during last one year and serum negative for S. typhi and S. paratyphi (A & B) antibodies (titre< 40) were selected. Group of 40 healthy individuals served as control. The psychiatric patients were started on chlorpromazine 2.5 mg three times a day orally. On 7th day 1 ml of formalised TAB vaccine (Glaxo) was injected subcutaneously. Blood was with-drawn on 15th and 30th days of inoculation and serum was tested for antibody titre by agglutination. The antibody titre was significantly lower in the chlorpromazine treated group against TO and TH on 15th day and against PA (H) and PB (H) also on 30th day. The parallel shift of the curves in the treated group as compared to the control suggests that only one mechanism is likely to be responsible for the reduction in antibody titre. It is …

title: Grain Refinement of Al--1. 25 Mn Alloy
author: VV Rao and AN Sinha and R Kumar
journal: All-India Seminar on Aluminium(Preprints), New Delhi, India, Oct. 1978,
abstract: See Met. A. . 8208-72-0355. The Al--1.25% Mn alloy produced by D.C. casting technique has a tendency to develop coarse grain size during recrystallization annealing of the cold rolled sheet. The roles of matrix supersaturation and dispersed precipitates on the recrystallization grain size are briefly discussed. The coarse precipitate particles by their effect on deformation substructure accelerate recrystallization. Precipitation from the supersaturated solid solution results in a fine dispersion of particles which hinder recrystallization. The effect of processing variables like composition. homogenization and rate of heating to recrystallization temperature on the recrystallized grain size are briefly described. 30 ref.--AA.

title: Adventures in Aluminium Alloy Melting Technology
author: R Kumar and CS Sivaramakrishnan
journal: All-India Seminar on Aluminium(Preprints), New Delhi, India, Oct. 1978,
abstract: See Met. A. . 8208-72-0355. Al melting technology is reviewed with reference to furnaces. degassing. filtration and grain refinement. Rheocasting using an agitated mixture of 30 to 40% pseudo solid is discussed with reference to Al--Si alloys. Advantages of using hyper-eutectic Al--20% Si alloys for automobile engine blocks are listed. 51 ref.--R.W.

title: Influence of Melting Technology on the Ageing Behaviour of Al--Mg and Al--Zn--Mg Alloys
author: RK Mahanti and CS Sivaramakrishnan and R Kumar

abstract: See Met. A. . 8208-72-0355. The results are described of precipitation hardening studied through hardness measurements in Al--Mg alloys as influenced by the melt treatments. namely. (i) vacuum stirring and (ii) filtration. The results obtained show improved precipitation behaviour as compared with similar alloys prepared by conventional methods. 23 ref.--AA.

title: Radiation induced early maturing mutants in barley
author: R Kumar and SVS Chauhan and RP Sharma
abstract: [en] In M 2 generation. two early maturing plants were screened from a single spike progeny of a plant obtained from 20 kR of gamma-ray irradiation of a six-rowed barley (Hordeum vulgare L. var. Jyoti). Their true breeding nature was confirmed in M 3 generation. These mutants flower and mature 38 and 22 days earlier than those of control.(auth.)

abstract: In a trial conducted for three years with K. Chandramukhi and K. Kuber variety of potato. Kufri Chandramukhi gave the highest yield. The difference of average rupees one thousand can be compensated by finding new varieties from existing new varieties coming up. There is great prospect for taking up rainy season crop. with meagre irrigation resources in the plateau of Chotanagpur.

title: Rationalization of the blading material for steam turbines: Their requirements and selection
author: Raghubir Singh and R Choubey and R Kumar
abstract: In steam turbines a wide range of blading materials. which are basically modified 12% Cr martensitic steel with additions of ferrite strengthening and carbide forming alloying elements viz. Mo. W. V. Nb etc. individually or in suitable combination. have been used. The choice of blading materials is to a large extent a function of design considerations. The grades used in different stages of steam turbine of a given capacity vary between different manufacturers. as is true with the three BHEL Units in India. Rationalization of blading materials both for HP and LP stages can lead to considerable saving on their development and testing cost. With this object in mind. a detailed and comparative study has been carried out of available grades of blading materials. The inter-relationships between chemical compositions. heat treatment. microstructure and their influence on long-term creep-rupture behaviour have been discussed in the light of the desired properties from design view points and service conditions. (Shri R. Singh. Shri R. Choubey and Dr. R. Kumar. Scientists. National Metallurgical Laboratory)

title: A Note on the Effect of Manuring and Branch Ringing on Bearing of Mango (Mangifera Indica Linn)
author: RK Sharma and Ram Kumar and VS Chhonkar
abstract: Irregular bearing is still a serious problem in mango. It is said primarily due to sub optimal carbohydrates and nitrogen reserves. inadequate leaf area and maturity condition of shoots. Various workers like Sen (5). Mallik (1) and Roy (4) have already recommended the practice of branch ringing and scoring along with manuring to get moderate crop along with manuring. With a view to study the influence of these cuts on branches six different types of cuts such as ringing. half girdling. notching. stripping. scoring and control were applied during September. The cultivars taken were Bombai. Hemsagar. Zardalu and Langra. The usual doses of fertilizers recommended for a mature tree were applied in two split doses in June and October.

title: Pharyngeal leiomyosarcoma
author: RP Kumar
abstract: A fourth case of leiomyosarcoma. first case in Oropharynx is reported. The tumour was pedunculated. attached to lateral pharyngeal wall and had rotated on its axis. This torsion has produced acute symptoms of dysphagia. bleeding from mouth and loss of weight. its management per-orally was easy. Other reported cases and its differential diagnosis is discussed.

title: Analysis of alloys and salt solutions by β‐ray backscattering
author: Aruna Bahadur and Krishna Das Maji and Rajendra Kumar
journal: Journal of applied chemistry and biotechnology
abstract: This investigation reports the results of a study undertaken to assess the suitability of using the GM counter for measuring the intensity of β‐backscattered radiation to determine the chemical composition of binary solid alloys. and aqueous salt solutions containing a metallic radical. The results indicate that the technique is not suitable for the determination of the composition of binary alloys since the error is in the range of 1.2–2.3 wt‐% metal. The technique can be conveniently adapted for aqueous salt solutions where the maximum error is approximately 0.2 wt‐% metal for metallic elements with atomic number greater than 20.

title: Journal Homepage:-www. journalijar. com
author: HAVING EARLIER MALE
abstract: Background: India leads in under-five child mortality. ARI and diarrheal diseases happen to be the most important causes responsible. Children residing in slum area are at risk owing to the environmental factors. This study aimed to determine the level of knowledge. describe the practice regarding ARI and diarrhoea of under-five children among mothers and find out any association of the knowledge level with the various factors influencing it. Methodology: This cross-sectional study performed in the months of August and September. 2014 was conducted on mothers with at least one living under-five child. whose families were permanent residents of the area. A predesigned pretested semi-structured schedule was used. on the participants chosen based on cluster sample design. Results: Study was conducted on 101 mothers. Mean educational level was up to 5th grade. 81.2% of the last born-children of the participants were delivered in hospitals. Majority of the mothers were aware about the danger signs and majority also sought medical care. Good practices were observed. which was assessed on mothers of 9 children suffering from ARI. 22 having cough with illnesses and 30 with diarrheal diseases. Though significant associations were not documented but this study found out the odds of having high knowledge level were more in favour of mothers in joint families. home-makers. having an earlier male child. upper socio-economic status. Conclusions: Homemakers living in an upper socioeconomic joint family. having a male child earlier had a high knowledge level. Most of the mothers were aware about the danger signs but knowledge …

title: WooL ProdUCed IN INdIA
author: DB Shakyawar and VV Kadam and Kumar Ajay
abstract: Wool. Nature’s gift to sheep. enjoys the status of being luxury fibre! The luxuriousness is owing to higher cost. ecofriedliness and inherent smart nature of the fibre. The cost of the fiber is largely influenced by its grade. The fibre grade is a numerical designation of wool fineness based on the average fiber diameter and variation of fiber diameter. It does not include characteristics such as length. crimp. strength. elasticity. luster. hand. and color--all of which affect on what is known as quality of either fibre. yarn or fabric (USDA. 1968). Wool produced all over the world is mainly grouped into three grades according to the end use viz. Apparel. carpet and coarse grade wool. The wools of below 25 microns diameter are known as apparel wool. wools of 25-35 micron are classified as medium or carpet grade wool and wools of more than 35 micron diameter are categorized as coarse wool (Karim SA. 2009).Indian wool quality varies with different agro-ecological regions. The north temperate region produces fine wool with lower medullation and higher staple length. The northwestern semi-arid and arid region produces carpet grade wool. Most of the wools in this region are of coarse grade with fibre diameter more than 35 microns. However. Bharat merino is the finest quality of wool produced in the Kodaikannal hills of the south peninsular region and the Kolar region of Karnataka. The wool quality is also largely depends upon climatic conditions and sheep breed. India has vast genetic resources in sheep. There are about 40-43 documented sheep breeds of sheep out of which 24 are distinct (Acharya. 1982; Bhatia et al.. 2004). India’s share to total number …

author: ZAHEER ABBAS KHAN and RACHANA KUMAR and JOYDEEP DUTTA
abstract: The templated growth of organic. inorganic and hybrid networks involving self-assembly with organogels. using tuned parameters. enables us to develop innovative nanostructures. In this research work. different strategies are employed to fabricate thin films using colloidal nanoparticles of metal and insulator materials. capped with organic polymers to provide stability and electrostatic binding forces to build heterogeneous devices.

title: Poor Shelf-life of Pearl Millet Flour-Approaches to Improve the Flour Quality
author: Suneha Goswami and RR Kumar and SP Singh and Tara C Satyavathi and Shelly Praveen
abstract: Despite nutritionally very rich and high medicinal value. the full potential of pearl millet flour is limited due to rancidity and off odour during storage. High fat content along with highly active lipases causes hydrolysis of fat into fatty acids. It contains 74% unsaturated fatty acids like oleic (C18: 1). linoleic (C18: 2). and linolenic (C18: 3). The lipase (triacylglycerol acyl hydrolase. EC 3.1. 1.3) enzyme is accumulated in the pericarp. aleurone layer and germ. This enzyme is responsible for stepwise hydrolysis of the triacyl glycerol into diacyl glycerol. monoacylglycerol. glycerol and short chain free fatty acids. Unsaturated fatty acids undergoes to oxidation in the presence of oxygen and moisture. resulting in development of undesired off odour. Pearl millet is also reported to contain oxidative enzyme such as peroxidase (Reddy et al.. 1986) and enzymatic browning. catalysed by enzyme such as polyphenol oxidase (PPO). both of which play important role in pearl millet flour quality deterioration. Hence. there are two type of rancidity mechanisms contribute to the development of off odour in pearl millet flour. First is enzymatic rancidity caused by lipase enzyme which results the release of free fatty acids. which further converted into phenolic aglycones. causes the generation of mousy odour. Poly phenol oxidase causes enzymatic browning. which results the generation of bitter compounds. Second mechanism is oxidative rancidity. caused by the lipoxygenase activity on free fatty acids and converted into hydro-peroxides and further through peroxidase activity. into aldehyde. ketones. polymers of peroxides etc. which is responsible for off odour development …

title: ANFIS based Automated System for the Detection of Gadolinium Lesions in Brain MRI
author: Rajesh Kumar and A Sivasankar
abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic disease that affects different parts of the central nervous system at different points of time. The central nervous system is made up of the brain and spinal cord. MS is an auto-immune disorder of the central nervous system characterized by the presence of Gadolinium lesions. In this paper. an intelligent technique is proposed for the automatic segmentation of Gadolinium lesions from the brain Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of MS patients. Since. manual interpretation of the lesions based on visual examination by radiologist/physician may lead to erroneous diagnosis when a large number of MRIs are analyzed; we propose an automated intelligent classification system. The proposed technique uses a trained classifier. Adaptive Neuro Fuzzy Interference System (ANFIS) to discriminate between the regions of MS lesions and non-MS lesion regions mainly based on the textural features. The proposed method consists of three stages. namely. preprocessing. feature extraction and classification. The classifier’s goal is to classify subjects as normal and abnormal brain MRI. The main contribution of the proposed technique described in this paper is the use of textural features like Gray level cooccurrence features. Local binary pattern features. Gray level based features. Histogram and Wavelet features to detect Gadolinium lesions in a fully automated approach that does not rely on manually delineating the lesions. The obtained results exhibit a sensitivity of 72% and maximum accuracy of 99% which assures that the proposed method would be viable for use in clinical practice for the detection of Gadolinium lesions …

title: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF ADVANCES IN
author: Richi Sinha and Rohit Kumar and Rakesh Kumar Singh
abstract: Craniopharyngiomas are relatively benign neoplasms of sellar or suprasellar region. The diagnosis is clinical and radiological. It is confirmed by characteristic histological findings. These unusual tumors should ideally be managed surgically in specialized centers and there is no role of systemic chemotherapy. We have discussed here the diagnosis and management of one such case of Craniopharyngioma with extensive spread and encroachment of vital structures. Careful surgical approach with expertise in these cases can save the patient from the associated morbidity and mortality.

title: Fertility & Nutrient Status of Bt Cotton Growing Soils in Kurnool District. Andhra Pradesh
author: S SATISH and YS SATISH KUMAR
abstract: A survey was undertaken to delineate the nutrient status in Bt cotton growing soils in Kurnool district of Andhra Pradesh. The analysis of the soils revealed that the texture of the soils varied from sandy clay loam to clay. neutral to strongly alkaline in reaction. non-saline. medium to high in organic carbon. medium in available nitrogen and high in available P and K. The available Ca. Mg. S. Fe. Mn. Zn Cu and B were found to be above their respective critical limits in all the soils. However. 53.33 per cent samples were deficient in available B in Alfisols.

title: Impact of Energy Management of EVs on Transient Voltage Stability of Microgrid
author: Muhammad Shoaib Khalid and Xiangning Lin and Yixin Zhuo and Ramesh Kumar and Muhammad Kashif Rafique
abstract: There is cause and effect relationship between increase in load due to increasing penetration of electric vehicles (EV) load that causes unbalanced conditions and affect the power quality such as voltage degradation and even damage the equipment if the system is not properly managed. This paper presents detailed review of energy supply and management in conjunction with load synchronization through EVs for maintaining transient voltage stability by providing reactive power support for the stability of power grid in vehicle-to-grid mode of operations. The energy management system is considered at different levels such as. stand-alone PV. stand-alone wind. stand-alone battery storage. stand-alone EV parking lot. residential feeder and commercial building feeders. First we proposed energy management algorithm. to limit the peak power drawn by EVs from distributed energy resources of microgrid. such that …

title: EUROPEAN JOURNAL OF PHARMACOLOGY & TOXICOLOGY
author: M Shankar and Roopa Kumar and B Ramesh and M Niranjan Babu
abstract: There are three accessible sources of autologous adult stem cells in humans are. Bone marrow. which requires extraction by harvesting. that is drilling into bone. Adipose tissue. which requires extraction by liposuction and Blood. which requires extraction through apheresis. where in blood is drawn from the donor. passed through a machine that extracts the stem cells and returns other portions of the blood to the donor. Tissue-specific stem cells. which are sometimes referred to as adult or somatic stem cells. are already somewhat specialized and can produce some or all of the mature cell types found within the particular tissue or organ. Recent developments in human stem cell research have raised hopes that new therapies will become available that will serve to relieve human suffering. These developments also have served to remind society of the deep moral concerns that are related to research involving human embryos and cadaveric fetal tissue. Serious ethical discussion will continue on these issues. We were persuaded that carrying out human stem cell research under federal sponsorship is important. but only if it is conducted in an ethically responsible manner. And after extensive deliberation. the Commission believes that acceptable public policy can be forged. in part. on widely shared views.
